etymologies: Middle English (in the sense ‘bundle’): from Old French trusse (noun), trusser‘pack up, bind in’, based on late Latin tors- ‘twisted’, from the verb torquere. truss (sense 1 of the noun) dates from the mid 17th century

definitions: a framework, typically consisting of rafters, posts, and struts, supporting a roof, bridge, or other structure
shortDefinitions: framework supporting a roof or other structure

definitions: a large projection of stone or timber, typically one supporting a cornice.
shortDefinitions: large projection of stone or timber

definitions: a surgical appliance worn to support a hernia, typically a padded belt.
shortDefinitions: surgical appliance worn to support hernia

definitions: a bundle of old hay (56 lb), new hay (60 lb), or straw (36 lb).
shortDefinitions: bundle of old hay 56 lb, new hay 60 lb

definitions: a compact cluster of flowers or fruit growing on one stalk.
shortDefinitions: compact cluster of flowers or fruit growing on one stalk

definitions: a heavy metal ring securing a lower yard to its mast.
shortDefinitions: heavy metal ring securing lower yards

definitions: tie up the wings and legs of (a chicken or other bird) before cooking

examples.text: Alfred had already trussed and stuffed the geese

shortDefinitions: tie up wings and legs of chicken or other bird before cooking

definitions: tie up (someone) with their arms at their sides

examples.text: I found him trussed up in his closet

shortDefinitions: tie up someone with their arms at their sides

definitions: dress (someone) in elaborate or uncomfortable clothing

examples.text: he was trussed up in a heavily padded suit, complete with face mask and protective gloves

shortDefinitions: dress someone in elaborate or uncomfortable clothing

definitions: support (a roof, bridge, or other structure) with a truss or trusses

examples.text: when they trussed the roof many things were overlooked.

shortDefinitions: support structure with truss or trusses
